Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Laser Amplification System for Sensitive, High-Resolution, Multi-Time Scale Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from The Major Research Instrumentation and Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities Programs, Professor Malcolm D. Forbes from Bowling Green University Main Campus and colleagues H. Peter Lu, Alexander Tarnovsky, Ksenija Glusac and Alexis Ostrowski have acquired an ultrafast laser amplification system. Ultrafast lasers are powerful tools in the investigation of photochemistry and photophysical processes such as the conversion of sunlight into energy as in solar cells or the production of carbohydrates in plants by photosynthesis. The time scale of such processes is often very fast, even femtoseconds (ten to minus fifteen seconds). The instrumentation is used in research and training by undergraduate and graduate students as well as high schools students preparing them for technical careers and advanced education.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas investigated at Bowling Green State University such as studying (a) fundamental research in solar energy conversion, (b) photocatalysis, (c) ultrafast molecular reactions, (d) proton-coupled electron transfer reactions, (e) water splitting reactions for the development of inexpensive alternative energy resources, (f) single molecule imaging of biomolecules and (g) the development of photo-tunable materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award made possible the construction of instrumentation used for a highly sophisticated experiment called ?pump-probe? transient absorption. This experiment enables the investigation of the structure, reactivity, and dynamics of chemical systems that have excess internal energy due to the absorption of light from ultrafast laser pulses (picosecond and femtosecond time scales). Obtaining spectroscopic information on such time scales provides information about the tiniest possible motions that atoms within molecules can make, and gives insight into how energy is dissipated within a molecular framework to relax back to the ground state. Understanding these processes can lead to more efficient catalysts for chemical synthesis, better initiators for the synthesis of important polymers, and improved performance of nanometer scale materials for solar energy conversion.

 

More specifically in terms of intellectual merit, researchers using this instrumentation in the Center for Photochemical Sciences at Bowling Green State University have learned that even when molecules have other possible relaxation mechanisms available that historically were believed to be dominant (spin-orbit coupling), a special type of molecular distortion, called the Jahn-Teller effect, can override the more dominant pathway. This was demonstrated in a complex involving Iridium, a metal which, when coordinated to the correct ligands, shows great promise for electro- and photocatalysis for low-cost molecular synthesis. In addition, a combined experimental/theoretical study of a copper complex explored intramolecular vibrational relaxation and discovered product partitioning to ionic products, competing with back electron transfer as a relaxation mechanism.

 

BGSU researchers also used this award to show that selective manipulation of nanoscale architectures in semiconducting materials can lead to longer lifetimes of electron-hole pairs known as excitons. Longer lived-excitons provide opportunities for fine-tuning the electric and optical properties of novel nanoscale particles such as quantum dots, which are used in visual display systems, infrared detection systems for driverless cars, and solar energy conversion devices.

 

The synthesis of polymers to make new materials, especially easily degradable ones for sustainability, is a major goal for chemists. Many polymerization reactions are initiated by short-lived reactive intermediates known as free radicals. This award allowed exploration of a new, stable and highly controllable molecular complex, called an ion pair, that can release free radicals for polymerization at precisely controlled rates. The instrumentation built with this award provided detailed information about the absorption and emission of light from several different states, as well as the directionality of electron transfer reactions that could influence the rate of radical production.

 

Finally, this award presented an opportunity to observe the effect of metal nanoparticles on the photoluminescence lifetimes of organic dyes. Because metal nanoparticles can be good electron acceptors, they can prolong the photoluminescence of dyes such as Alexa 488 and Cy5. The results have implications for the construction of more sensitive biosensors, and may find applications in molecular and biomedical imaging.

 

In addition to the broader scientific impact of the outcomes presented above by the Principal Investigator and co-Principal Investigators, this award had a tremendous broader impact by providing educational opportunities and career advancement for nine young researchers: five graduate students, two postdoctoral research associates, and two undergraduate BGSU students. These young scientists received excellent training in the intricacies of 1) theory of ultrafast spectroscopy, 2) experimental approaches to ultrafast spectroscopy with the emphasis on the pump-probe method, including hands-on training on ultrafast amplified regenerative laser systems, non-linear optical converters, optics, and optomechanics, and 3) femtosecond pump-probe data analysis and presentation.
